awd_titl_txt: I-Corps Teams:  VSTEP Digital Health Platform
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps VSTEP Digital Health project is to increase clinician efficiency and engagement with therapy for persons with neurological conditions such as post-stroke and with Parkinson Disease.   Using off-the shelf hardware and custom software decreases cost both for equipment purchase and providing care. It also facilitates that clinics of all sizes can adopt innovative technology in treatment of patients.  Customization of therapy may increase clinician productivity, enhance outcomes and decrease treatment time. Insights on patient and clinician performance can help clinics and insurance providers lower costs and provide better care. Societal impact may be achieved by providing an engaging therapy that increases socialization and decrease loneliness and most importantly increases activity and participation in society. The project will facilitate a decision about whether to pursue further development and commercialization of the technology.

This I-Corps project seeks to explore the commercial potential of The VSTEP Digital Health Platform which is an integrated solution for the comprehensive examination and treatment of balance, mobility, coordination and fitness deficits of persons with neurologic conditions. These deficits which occur frequently after neurologic diagnosis, persist when not treated and interfere with activity and participation in societal roles. The technology integrates motion and heart rate sensing with activity based engaging therapeutic games presented in a virtual environment. It also has an examination suite which uses standardized assessments that guide the therapeutic activities. Customization of the therapy ensures that the patient's goals are achieved and the clinicians? insights and reasoning for care are incorporated with the technology.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

inst.inst_name: RUTGERS, THE STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW JERSEY

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: RUTGERS, THE STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW JERSEY

por.por_cntn:
The project was focused around learning if the VSTEP technology (using a Kinect camera to track movement and heart rate while displaying it on a virtual screen) would be a useful tool to enhance physical therapists? assessments and treatments of persons with neurologic health conditions such as stroke or Parkinsons Disease. The VSTEP technology has activity based therapeutic games and evidence-based assessments of motor performance and fitness.

 

The project consisted of conducting 150 interviews with potential customers, distributors and other people in the rehabilitation space.  Outcomes of this project that served to Advance Knowledge include 1. There is interest in using tools that will make assessment and documentation easier. 2. There is an opportunity to use this technology as tool to prepare clinicians as well as make it easier for them to practice. 3. The proposed cost of the technology and its potential benefit were favorably received.

Benefit Society: The technology may make it easier for clinicians to assess their patients and document their progress. Good assessments lead to better clinical outcomes and reduced time in rehabilitation. Further it may enhance the education of physical therapists.


The technology was revised and tested with clinicians, educators and students for its ease of use and usefulness. The student experienced was presented at an international conference for virtual reality and received the best poster award. This project involved people across the professions of physical therapy, science, engineering, education and medicine. Students the fields of engineering, science and rehabilitation and medicine participated and received training through this project.

 


Last Modified: 10/19/2021
Modified by: Judith Deutsch
